_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

a.    Davis Supply is a supplier of water treatment chemicals for small, local, public and private water treatment facilities.  The Polk County facility is located at 15493 South Highway 27 in Lake Wales, Florida [27.845186 North latitude and 81.584831 West longitude].  A site location map is included as Figure 1 at the end of the executive summary.  This office/warehouse facility includes a chlorine storage area within the warehouse area, which contains 150-pound cylinders of chlorine in storage cages toward the west end of the warehouse facility.  Empty cylinders are stored chained adjacent to the full cylinder storage area.  A maximum inventory level of 48 cylinders or 7,200 pounds of chlorine gas will be stored on site at any time.  A site drawing is included at the end of the executive summary as Figure 2.  Based on the maximum inventory levels, only chlorine will be subject to the RMP standard.  No recognized public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint for the worst-case release.  This facility does not fall into any of the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) codes as listed in the RMP standard.  As a primarily retail business (i.e. selling to end users) with less than 10 full time employees on site, this facility does not meet the requirements for regulation under the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard.   This facility therefore qualifies as a Program 2 facility under U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) guidelines.  

b.    It is anticipated that no more than four (4) people will be employed by the facility.  Currently the facility employs three (3) people - two 2 drivers and one (1) office manager.  The facility is generally staffed by 1 person during the normal business hours of 0800 hours to 1600 hours, Monday through Friday.  A corporate emergency phone number [(800) 749-5947] is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

c.    The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration

of two chlorine-related release scenarios, identified as "worst-case release" and "alternative release."  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that, "the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes," due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario".

(1.)     The worst-case release scenario at this Davis Supply facility involves the release of the contents of a single 150-pound chlorine cylinder in 10 minutes.  An offsite consequence analysis for this scenario was performed based on calculations provided by the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Chemical Distributors (January 27, 1999) document.  This scenario followed conditions pre-defined by the EPA, namely release of the entire amount as a gas in 10 minutes, use of the one-hour average ERPG-2 (3 ppm) as the toxic endpoint, and consideration of the population residing within a full circle with radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance. These conditions were set by the EPA to facilitate the performance of the offsite consequence analysis; and the assumptions do not likely reflect realistic results.  The toxic endpoint based on EPA assumptions was estimated to be to be 0.4 miles.  The population within the entire 0.5 square mile toxic endpoint potential impact area with a radius of 0.4 miles for this scenario was estimated to be 63 people using the LandView 6 software with Census 2000 data.  Figure 3 depicts the worst-case scenario 0.4-mile toxic endpoint potential impact area with a smaller plume shown to the North to depict the prevailing wind the majority of the year as provided by the National Climatic Data Center and, therefore, most likely impact direction.  Public receptors within the area contained in a circle with its center at the Davis Supply facility and outwards at a radius of 0.4 miles were noted as follows:


        Public,

Non-Residential Receptors
None Noted
        Environmental Receptors
None Noted
        Major Commercial, Office, or Industrial Buildings.
None Noted

(2.)  The alternative release scenario involves valve failure on a single 150-pound cylinder.  From the Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 74, Estimating the Area Affected by a Chlorine Release, the release rate for the valve of a 1-ton container of chlorine is 12.7 pounds per minute.  The only difference between the valve of a 1-ton container and 150-pound cylinder is the presence of a fusible plug on the 1-ton container.  The release rates therefore would be expected to be the same.  Based on the calculations as provided by the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Chemical Distributors (January 27, 1999) document the toxic endpoint for the alternative scenario was estimated to be 0.1 miles.  Figure 4 depicts the alternative release scenario 0.1-mile toxic endpoint potential impact area with a smaller plume shown to the North to depict the most likely impact direction.  The population within the entire 0.03 square mile toxic endpoint potential impact area with a radius of 0.1 miles for this scenario was estimated to be 0 people using the LandView 6 software with Census 2000 data.  Public receptors within the area contained in a circle with its center at the Davis Supply facility and outwards at a radius of 0.1 miles were noted as follows:

        Public, Non-Residential Receptors
None Noted
        Environmental Receptors
            None Noted
        Major Commercial, Office, or Industrial Buildings
            None Noted

d.    The Davis Supply accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
A?    Training of chlorine handlers
A?    Supplier provided cylinder preventive maintenance program
A?    Use of industry standard process and safety equipment

Chlorine-specific prevention steps include:
A?    Training in the practices of safe chlorine handling
A?    Awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine

e.    No accidental releases of chlor

ine have occurred at this facility in the past five years.

f.    Emergency response procedures are coordinated with local emergency responders, as this facility has limited emergency response capabilities. In the event of an emergency, 911 is contacted, and the site is evacuated. The non-emergency number for the Lake Wales Fire Department is (863) 678-4203.
